newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnia's local polls to be postponed again - sources.
newsitem.headline: Bosnia's local polls to be postponed again - sources.

text.p: Bosnia's hotly-contested municipal elections, originally proposed for July, will probably be postponed until September, Western officials said on Tuesday.
"No firm date has been set, but it looks like the two days of elections in September will be 13th and 14th," an official said.
The local polls were originally supposed to be held in September 1996, along with general elections, but were postponed because of widespread election fraud over refugee registration.
The municipal vote was moved to November last year and then July of this year.

Western countries funding the election were pushing for a third postponement of the local polls to allow more time to organise refugee registration and international monitoring of the voting, officials said.

"A bit more time is needed to get all the issues sorted out -- getting the money on tap, getting the international supervisors into Bosnia and making sure the refugee registration process works well," the official said.
The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), which is supervising the elections, needs $50 to $55 million to organise the vote, the official said.
The next round of nationwide elections are set for 1998, a year after the scheduled municipal balloting in September.
A spokeswoman for the OSCE declined to confirm the postponement but said a statement would be issued on Thursday.

Bosnia's local polls are viewed as the country's last chance for reunification after a devastating 43-month war. The vote is supposed to enable refugees to elect authorities in their former towns and reverse the effects of wartime ethnic expulsions.
Hundreds of thousands of people were uprooted by the war and their votes could change the leadership in municipalities ruled by officials attempting to seal their control over conquered territory.
Bosnian Serbs were charged with manipulating registration of people displaced inside the country, pushing them to vote in the towns where they had resettled.
Thousands of Serb refugees in neighbouring Yugoslavia were registered for voting in Bosnian towns where Moslems had held a pre-war majority but were expelled during the war.
In an attempt to prevent election fraud, the OSCE said it would place one international supervisor at each of 2,300 polling stations across the country.
